Chapter on the King's Messengers Going and Returning, Part 2
At that time, King Åšuddhodana said again:
My wise son!
Although you now have no love and affection for your relatives, just consider my feelings and return home, so that I do not now take my own life out of grief and distress for you.
Good son!

Those who practice the Dharma should give rise to a compassionate mind towards all sentient beings. Only then can they be called Dharma practitioners. How can it be that only entering the deep mountains is called practicing the Dharma?
Why is it so?

I have heard that in the past, there were people who, in their own homes, did not remove their necklaces and various ornaments, let their beards and hair grow, and, in order to seek liberation, were able to attain the Dharma of liberation while still in the household.
The practice of the Dharma of liberation only requires wisdom and diligence, as this is the true cause of liberation.
If you now go against me and enter the mountains, this would be avoiding the five desires and the Dharma of fear.
However, those who attained liberation while in the household, with various necklaces adorning their bodies, I will now briefly explain for you.

In the past, there were benevolent ones named Suixiang, Renzhe, Lijinjie, Renzhe, Duoyou, Renzhe, Xingliu, Renzhe, Dafu, Renzhe, Biantian, and also the king of Videha named Nengsheng Yeyedi Wang (Skt. Cakravarti-rÄja), benevolent one, Pure Immortal, and King RÄma (Skt. RÄma), there were such innumerable and boundless kings in the household, all of whom attained liberation.
You should now know that seeking the Dharma of liberation in the home can also lead to attainment, not necessarily leaving the household.
Therefore, you should quickly return home to fulfill two kinds of wishes:
First, you will be able to enjoy the five desires;
Second, it will always bring joy to my heart.
For ordinary people in the world who receive the position of king, if it can bring about the ability to fulfill their wishes, it is called a true king.

I can now fulfill this wish for you. The position of king is difficult to relinquish, but for your sake, I can relinquish this difficult thing and give it to you, anointing you on the crown of your head.
If you establish such causes and conditions, then I will be delighted and will immediately take leave, renounce the world, and enter the mountains to seek the Way.'
And he spoke a verse, saying:
'The position of king is truly difficult to relinquish, but now I will cut it off completely and entrust it to you.
Seeing that you are capable of governing the world, I will be delighted and immediately enter the mountains.'

At that time, the great ministers, the national preceptor, and the brÄhmanas proclaimed to the Bodhisattva in detail the oral decree and the verses spoken by King Åšuddhodana, and again separately advised the Bodhisattva with three kinds of intentions, saying:
'Great wise holy son!
This is the tearful and choked decree of your father, King Åšuddhodana, towards us, with words of bitterness.
Therefore, holy son!
Now hearing the king's painful decree like this, you should make offerings and respectfully obey the king's decree, and should not go against it.

The holy son's father, the king, is now drowning in a great, deep river of suffering, and no one can pull him out to the shore of wisdom. Only the holy son can save and protect him, and can pull him out of that suffering.
It is just like falling into the deepest water, and only a great ship captain can pull one out.
In this way, in this way, the holy son's father, the king, is now drowning in a great, deep ocean of suffering, and there is no one else who can pull him out, only the holy son.
Moreover, holy son, when you were a small infant, it was only GautamÄ« who raised and nurtured you, and she is also your aunt. Do not let her be orphaned and widowed, causing her to die.
Now, thinking of the holy son, she suffers greatly. It is like a cow whose calf has died, crying out in grief.
It is just like this. That GautamÄ«, because she cannot see the prince, is crying sadly and constantly weeping. Therefore, the prince should not abandon her.
Moreover, because of the kindness of raising and nurturing in the past, she is like a cow who loves her calf. And the women of the inner palace and the retinue are also suffering.
Furthermore, all the ÅšÄkya men, women, and people, young and old, in the city of Kapila are tormented by their love for the prince and are being burned by the fire of suffering.
Therefore, prince!
Now you should return home and see them, just as when the great earth is burned, the gods above send down sweet rain to extinguish the intense fire of burning heat.

At that time, the Bodhisattva, having heard these words from the messenger of the father king, contemplated for a short while, and after adjusting his body, speech, and breath, he replied to the messenger, saying:
'I have long known that fathers love their sons, and I know that my father, King Åšuddhodana, has great affection and longing for me.
But I am now afraid of birth, old age, sickness, and death in the world. If I myself am drowning, how can I save others?
I want to seek liberation, so I have left behind all my relatives.
Who would willingly abandon these loved ones, if not wanting to always see each other?
If there were no separation from loved ones in the world, who would not enjoy the world?
Although I may stay for a long time with my relatives, we will eventually be separated. Therefore, I now abandon all loved ones, relatives, parents, and aspire to seek enlightenment.
If what you say is true, because of loving me, it causes the father king to give rise to great suffering.
I, upon hearing these words, truly do not cling to such love and affection.
Why is it so?

It is like a person who, in a dream, sees their loved ones gathering together, and upon waking, they are separated again. If it is an ordinary person who does not understand skillful means, their mind will give rise to suffering and distress, and this is a foolish being who lacks discernment.

If there is a wise person who is able to reflect on their own, thinking that the gathering of loved ones is like travelers on a road forming companions and traveling together, following each other near and far, reaching their destination, and then each dispersing back to their origins.
For this reason, loved ones and relatives gather and then separate. Why is it necessary to be sorrowful and distressed?
Moreover, in past lives, they have already been relatives and have left to come here;
In this place, relatives have left to go to the next world;
Having left this place, they will go to another place in the next world;
In this way, they will continue to abandon each other. Where does the mind of love and attachment for these relatives come from?
Where does it go to?
All worldly people, from the moment of conception, wherever they go, in this way, moment by moment, in every instant, are all followed by the ghost of death.
What is this?
Is it the right time or the wrong time?
Now he tells me:
My son, this is not the time to enter the mountains to seek the Way.
How much more so when at home, enjoying the five desires?
If he asks me about the right time and the wrong time, I will now briefly explain.
Why is this?

Because the ghost of death, at all times, seizes all beings, there is no time when it does not seize, therefore I now wish to seek to be free from birth, old age, sickness and death, for this reason, there is no right time or wrong time.
The Bodhisattva said again:
If my father calls his son to come, I will definitely bestow the position of crown prince on my son.
My father must have a great vow in his heart, it is difficult to do such things, but he is able to give them to me, it is a pity that he makes me not cultivate the Way.
But I do not wish to accept this kingly position, because being bound by familial love is not the path to liberation.
It is like a sick person not thinking of delicious food. How can a wise person crave these worldly pleasures?
Because the ignorant mind and foolish body have much suffering and distress, one can only accept this kingly position.

Having occupied the kingly position, one is unrestrained and self-indulgent, addicted to alcohol and sex, unable to let go. It is like a golden house blazing with raging fire, like delicious juice mixed with poisonous drugs, like a flower pond with a crocodile.
In this way, in this way, the kingly position is pleasurable, delightful to the mind, but troubles follow, one is unaware and unknowing.
For this reason, I am now unhappy, and this is not the Dharma.'
And he spoke a verse, saying:
'It is like a golden house with raging fire, like delicious food mixed with poisonous drugs,
like a pond full of flowers with a crocodile - after the pleasures of the kingly position come great suffering.'
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had spoken this verse, he further said:

Because of this, the kings of the past, after attaining the throne, enjoyed the pleasures of governance when they were young, but later in their old age, they became disgusted with the five desires, abandoned their palaces and entered the mountains and forests.

It is better for ordinary people to live in the mountains and forests, eating grass to sustain their lives, than to dwell in palaces and enjoy the pleasures of the five desires, like raising a black snake, and later suffering its calamity.
When first experiencing pleasure, one does not know the harm it will bring. Later, when anger arises, one will eventually bite others.
It is better to abandon one's home and enter the mountains and forests, than to abandon the mountains and forests and return to one's home.
Why is this?
Because it is despised by the sages of the past.
Now that I have been born into a good family, I should cultivate good dharmas, and not like a foolish person who practices unwholesome dharmas and indulges his mind.
Having shaved their beards and hair, put on the dyed robes, and stayed in the mountains and forests to cultivate the path and study,
they later abandon the dyed robes and do not feel ashamed. This is called a shameless foolish person.
Either for the sake of greed, or for the sake of anger, or for the sake of delusion, or out of fear of others, they thus retreat.
I now do not envy the palace of Åšakra, king of the devas, let alone wanting to return to my own house?
It is like a person who has obtained delicious food and eaten it, and later vomits it up and discards it on the ground, wanting to eat it again. Is that possible?
It is just like this. If a person abandons the five desires and goes forth, and for various reasons wants to return to the household life, it is also like this.
It is like a person who has already left a house on fire, wanting to return.
It is just like this. Having seen the sufferings of the world, abandoning the form of a layperson, entering the mountains to cultivate the path, returning is also like this.
And spoke this verse:
Just as a person abandons a burning house and runs away, but later suddenly returns again,
Having seen the troubles of the world and left home to become a renunciant, returning from the forest to home is also like this.
At that time, after the Bodhisattva had spoken this verse, he said to the two messengers:
What you two previously said about the father king's statement that the kings of the past who cultivated the Dharma at home attained liberation, that is not so.
Why is it so?
These two things are very far apart, with their causes and conditions contradicting each other.
Why is it so?
For one who seeks liberation, the mind must be tranquil and still, and only then can one dwell in a subtle place.

If one is in the palace, the five desires will be rampant. If one goes outside to govern the people, one must use whips and canes, anger and scolding, and punishments. In such a mind, seeking liberation is impossible.
If a person's mind is tranquil and free from afflictions, they will not crave worldly kingship. Even if they are in a position of power, they should abandon it.
If one delights in kingship, their mind cannot be tranquil.
If one delights in tranquil concentration but also craves worldly affairs, these two are incompatible, as distant as heaven and earth, like water and fire that cannot coexist.
It is the same with seeking the Dharma of liberation while being attached to the five desires. This is impossible.
Therefore, I now definitely know that those kings of the past abandoned their positions of power and then attained the Dharma of tranquil concentration.

If they were ruling the kingdom and teaching, their wisdom was not yet complete, so they were merely learning to govern the people with their minds, not necessarily exclusively seeking the Dharma of liberation.
Although this is the case, those kings each followed their own intentions, some seeking liberation, some indulging in the five desires;
I am not like them now, I do not learn from them, and I have never given rise to such a mind.
I have now severed the fetters of desire for the household life, attained liberation, and no longer crave the five desires of the world. How could I return home?'

At that time, the two messengers heard the Bodhisattva's such-like explanations of non-attachment, his focused, determined, and truthful words, and again they discussed together and said to the Bodhisattva:
'Great Sage Prince!
Now, your vow to seek the unsurpassed Dharma is true, not without reason.
But this practice is not yet timely.
Why is it so?
The holy prince's father, the king, is now suffering such sorrow and distress. Therefore, holy prince!
Going against his wishes is not the right Dharma.'
And they spoke a verse, saying:
'Now seeking the Dharma treasury is truly beneficial, although there is right principle, it is not yet timely,
The grief and pain of the father king, filial piety and virtue are already lost, what is the way?
At that time, after the two messengers had spoken this verse, they again addressed the holy prince, saying:
Great holy prince!
As we see it, this intention is not a subtle observation of the Dharma, but a skillful means regarding worldly wealth and the five desires.
Why is it so?
Holy prince, you have never seen the cause before, how can you seek the fruit?
You now obtain the fruit of retribution, yet you abandon it and seek the future.
Great holy prince!
All the scriptures in the world each have their own principles. Some people say:
There is a future world.
Some people say:
There is no future world.
However, in this matter, many people have doubts.
Therefore, holy prince!
If there is no future world, why should one diligently strive to seek liberation?
Some people say:
There is definitely good and evil in the world, and one receives them in the future world.
For this reason, one diligently practices and seeks the path to liberation. This is called foolishness.

If the faculties are definitely destroyed, loved ones are separated, and enemies gather, and the characteristics of objects naturally separate, and one is born, grows old, gets sick, and dies, why should one make diligent efforts?
One should know that this meaning is not real.
When in the womb, hands, feet, chest, back, belly, hair, nails, joints, and blood vessels are naturally formed.
Some people say that after the body is formed, it is destroyed again. Some people say:
After it is destroyed, it is naturally formed again.
Therefore, the ancient scriptures have such words:
Who ground to a point the thorns and needles?
Who painted the various colors on birds and beasts?
This meaning is natural, created by no one, and also cannot be obtained by mere desire. The various things in the world cannot be turned around at will.
There is a verse that says:
Who ground to a point the thorns and needles?
Who painted the various colors on birds and beasts?
Each according to their karma, turning and changing, the world has no creator.
Another person said:
The creator of the world is all created by the Lord God. If it were natural, why would people still need to work hard?
It is not that the cause of transmigration comes from itself, and when it goes, it still goes with that cause of transmigration.
Another person said:
Because of discrimination, the notion of self arises, so one experiences existence, and the end of existence is the same;
If there is a time of receiving, it does not depend on diligent seeking, but is naturally received;
If there is a time of exhaustion, it naturally ends, and does not depend on cessation.
There are also people who say:
When the world wishes to receive a human body, if the father does not owe debts to others, then it can be born. Birth in heaven and birth as a celestial being are all like this.

If these three places do not owe debts, then this person does not need to diligently seek, but naturally attains liberation in those places. In this way, the various scriptures each have their own doctrines, each attaining liberation.
Those who are wise and diligent in seeking a superior place will certainly harm their minds.
Therefore, I know that if the prince wishes to seek liberation, he should rely on principles and the Dharma to seek the path to liberation as it is explained in the ancient scriptures and doctrines.
If it is so, you will definitely attain it, there is no doubt.
The holy son's kind father, King Åšuddhodana, will be relieved of the suffering of loving thoughts for the holy son.
When the holy son returns to the palace now, if he feels aversion towards the palace in his mind, he should also not think about it.
Why is it so?
In the past, the kings and sages, after abandoning their homes and going to the mountains and forests, later returned to their own palaces.

You should not have such thoughts now. I will make a vow. Even if the sun and moon fall to the ground, and this snow mountain king moves from its original place, if I have not yet attained the true Dharma treasure, and for the sake of worldly affairs return to my original palace with an ordinary person's body, it would be impossible.

At that time, the two messengers, having heard such words from the Bodhisattva, and seeing that he was determined to abandon all relatives, made such a vow, knowing that he would definitely not turn back, threw themselves to the ground, rose from the ground, tears filling their faces, and cried out in loud voices, following the Bodhisattva's steps, wanting to approach the Bodhisattva.

At that time, the Bodhisattva's majestic virtue was very great, and those two people were unable to approach him, just as the sunlight dazzles their eyes and they are unable to see the Bodhisattva's body.

'You people!
Do not leave the Holy Son and see where he goes.
Having instructed them in this way, at that time the two men were sorrowful in their hearts, suffering greatly, crying and wailing, and asked each other:

Walking with ease and skill, glancing like a great bull king,

At that time, after the young man had praised the Bodhisattva with this verse, he again said to the young men,
'You all, young men!

At that time, after the Bodhisattva had sat on the grass mat, Arahant carefully observed the Bodhisattva's body, looking up and down, and gave rise to a great sense of joy and wonder. He then spoke to the Bodhisattva in a beautiful voice, engaging in conversation and praising the Bodhisattva, saying:
'Virtuous Gautama!
I have long heard that you, a great man,
are able to abandon your royal status, leave the city, and cut off your loved ones' entangling affections.
It is like a great elephant breaking free from strong iron chains or rough leather ropes, and after being suddenly freed, it goes wherever it pleases.
In the same way, you, today, are able to fiercely abandon the palace and enter the mountains, being content with little in all places and having great wisdom.
Virtuous Gautama!

Having obtained such rare things, worldly wealth and status, the results and functions of karmic retribution, and having been able to abandon them, to shave one's head and enter the mountains, this is truly difficult to accomplish.

In the past, although the kings obtained the fruits of the king's position and were fully endowed with the five desires, when they reached old age, they called the crown prince, entrusted the king's position to him, and had him enthroned as king. Only then did they leave the palace and go to the mountains and forests to seek the Way.
That is not difficult, nor is it rare.

As I see it, you are young, have not experienced the five desires, and have abandoned the pursuit of wealth and status. You are able to cultivate this aspiration and come here seeking the Way. Having attained such an inconceivable great king's position, the most supreme realm, in the prime of your youth, you are able to focus your mind and not be attached to desires. Aspiring to liberation, you are not bound or attached. You are not tainted by the objects of the senses. You know all the afflictions within existence and are not entangled by the bonds of existence.
Why is this so?

In the past there was a king named King of the Peak. That king had already unified the four continents under his rule, yet he was still not content. He ascended to the Heaven of the Thirty-three and sat on half of Åšakra's seat. Because his inner mind was not content, the objects of the five desires immediately disappeared and he fell back to the ground.

There was also a king named Naohou Sha who obtained the rule of the four continents and ascended to the thirty-three heavens to govern the gods, but he was still not content and lost his royal status and fell back to earth.

Kings such as these, such as King Rama, King Daluhuomi, King Asha Luozha, and many other wheel-turning sage kings, because they were not content with their royal status, all lost their realms, wealth, nobility, and royal positions, all of which came to an end.
There is no one in the world who, having obtained a realm, knows contentment, just as a great fire becomes more and more intense when it gets fuel.'
When Arahala had said this, the Bodhisattva replied:
'Virtuous Great Sage!
I see such phenomena in the world, and I also observe that everything is like a plantain tree, with no solidity inside, and will eventually be destroyed.
Having attained the realm, fearing dissatisfaction, not seeking self-benefit, and being disgusted with desires.

Knowing this, I sought the right path, wandering everywhere, just like a person walking in the wilderness, losing companions and getting lost, the mind confused by the directions, not finding a guide, seeking a guide, wandering everywhere, now I am also like this.'

'This person is inconceivable, able to accomplish this mind.

In the past, when the kings were young, they sat in the palace to enjoy the five desires. Later, when they became old with white hair, they each called their prince, entrusted the kingdom to him, had him consecrated as king, and then left home to enter the mountains and forests, practicing the path and becoming royal sages.

This is not the case. In the prime of youth, when one is vigorous, it is precisely the time to enjoy the five desires with a happy mind. With few illnesses and few troubles, one's physical strength is sufficient, one's hair is black, one's body is soft, one is full of vigor, and nothing is lacking.
The father king is old and does not covet the kingdom. He is disgusted with the world and does not crave rewards. He is able to leave home, enter the mountains, and seek the path.'
Then Alara said to the Bodhisattva:

That you are able to give rise to this mind and come to this place.'
The Bodhisattva replied:
'Venerable Great Master!
I see that sentient beings in this world are bound by birth, old age, sickness, and death, unable to escape on their own, and now I give rise to such a diligent mind.'

Why is it so?
' And he spoke a verse, saying:
'The supreme of all dharmas is only practice, pure and still concentration is nothing but the mind,
Attachment to affection is the greatest enemy, all fears are old age and death.'
At that time, after AralÄ said this, there was a young man in the assembly who was a disciple of AralÄ the sage. He said to the Bodhisattva:
'Good man, you have now abandoned your loved ones and relatives, turning your back to come here. What is your intention?'
The Bodhisattva replied:
